title: Wednesday, 16th August, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:04am

Guess who forgot Murph was on diversity training this morning?

BE11:05am

I was just moaning to Arash about things and stuff, didn't notice the time tick past 11am. Completely forgot I'm in charge of ML today.

BE11:05am

(@ROTR: yes, the dance troupe. I've no idea what you're talking about but am nodding slowly anyway.)

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Anyway, upshot here is that I've forgotten a picture as well.

BE11:06am

So .... uh, have literally the last thing in my inbox.

BE11:07am

Former 2* Michelin chef James Cochran opens new London restaurant

11:07 am
BE11:07am

https://tinyurl.com/ya4pdyag

BE11:07am

On behalf of popular chef, James Cochran, CBRE Global Investors has announced today (August 15) his new restaurant has opened on Friday August 11 at Angel Central shopping mall, Islington.
The restaurant, spanning 2,111 sq-ft, has approximately 60 covers inside and 20 covers on the terrace space., along with a cocktail and wine bar as well as a DJ booth for evening entertainment.
Named James Cochran N1, the eatery even features an open-plan kitchen which allows diners to see the famous chef cook his signature dishes including the popular meal of Caribbean jerk chicken.

BE11:07am

No!

11:07 am
BE11:07am

There is a number of things wrong with this.

BE11:08am

First, Michelin stars are for places not people.

BE11:08am

(And people who care about Michelin stars are dorks, but we can put that aside for a moment.)

11:08 am
BE11:09am

Second, even if stars were for people not places it'd be a bit off to call James a "former 2* Michelin chef"

BE11:09am

He was chef de partie at the Ledbury

BE11:09am

Chef de partie means you run a section.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Ledbury's head chef was, and is, Brett Graham.

BE11:10am

Anyway, good luck to James and his something or other in a shopping mall opposite Angel Tube station, next to the Vue cinema and the Superdry.

BE11:10am

And bad form, CBRE Global Investors. Sort out your press releases.

11:10 am
undefined
BE11:11am

So, sterling down FTSE up.

BE11:11am

0.7% at pixel. 7432.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Jobs data the catalyst for GBP.

BE11:13am

Unemployment rate at its lowest since 1975, wage growth faster than forecast.

BE11:14am

... .but it probably still slow enough not to worry about, from the perspective of rates.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

That's HSBC's opinion anyway.

BE11:15am

UK employment rose by 125k in the three months to June. In the 12 months to June, employment has risen by 338k - that is above historic average increases.
The employment rate (for those aged 16-64) reached a new record high of 75.1%, while the unemployment rate edged down from 4.5% to 4.4% (consensus 4.5%). That is a fresh 42-year low and 0.1ppt below the MPC's view of 'equilibrium' unemployment.
Whole economy total pay growth rose from 1.8% to 2.1% 3m/yr. That was stronger than consensus expectations for an unchanged growth rate.
But part of this surprise was driven by volatile bonus payments. Regular wage growth (ie excluding bonuses) rose from 2.0% to 2.1% 3m/yr. That was 0.1ppt above consensus. In month-on-month terms, the level of regular pay was unchanged in June.
Nominal wage growth is still running below inflation, such that real wage growth is still in negative territory. Specifically, regular real pay growth remained at -0.5% 3m/yr

BE11:16am

So .....

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Although wages have ticked up marginally, the story of strong employment and weak wages is still very much intact. A simple look at the relationship between unemployment and wage growth would suggest that, with the jobless rate this low, annual wage growth should be around twice as strong as it currently is (Chart 1). We have discussed various possible reasons for this, including underemployment, weak productivity growth, and a range of global technological forces eroding the bargaining power of labour. Is might be a while before these downward pressures on wage growth unwind. A counterpart to continued employment strength, alongside sluggish GDP growth, is weakness in productivity. GDP grew by a tepid 1.7% y-o-y in Q2, while employment grew by a decent 0.8% y-o-y. So productivity grew by 0.8% y-o-y. That is soft, relative to the pre-2008 average growth rate of around 2%. It is striking that the headwinds facing the UK economy -- Brexit-related uncertainty and the inflation squeeze on household income -- have appeared to depress productivity rather than hiring and employment.

BE11:16am

Despite weak productivity, unit wage costs remain low. The evolution of these costs, which make up the lion's share of firms' overall costs, are determined by the balance between wage growth and cost-saving productivity growth. Even though productivity growth remains limp, continued weakness in wage growth means that we estimate that regular unit wage costs grew by 1.2% in Q2 -- well below average.
Continued weakness in unit wage costs is a key reason why, even while sterling effects are driving headline inflation above the BoE's 2% target, the MPC appears in no mood for an imminent rate hike (bar two hawkish dissenters). Granted, the jobless rate has fallen below 'equilibrium', but the MPC had already forecast a 4.4% unemployment print for June in its August Inflation Report. All else equal, this development would offer scope to tighten policy. But with labour costs as weak as they are, and with Brexit risks also looming, our view is that the MPC will keep rates on hold throughout this year and next.

BE11:17am

So ..... why's wage growth weak and unemployment low?

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Shouldn't the latter put upward pressure on the former?

BE11:18am

Shouldn't the latter put upward pressure on the former?

BE11:18am

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Doesn't really make sense to me. Is there some kind of "quality of employment" gauge in existence? I'd like to see that.

undefined
BE11:20am

@Flaneur: yep, we seem to be having occasional tech problems.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

@Flaneur: also, please don't call me PM. I can't live up to that kind of billing.

BE11:21am

So .... in terms of corporate ..............

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 2,056, down 122 (-5.60%), High: 2,078, Low: 1,984, Volume: 1.21m
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Results are okay rather than good. Guidance on the market is a bit cautious and clarity on the capital position has been pushed back a year.

BE11:23am

Also, they were on 20x 2018. Which is a lot for a motor insurer, at the top of an irresistibly cyclical sector.

BE11:23am

Also, note the earnings are helped along by one-offs. Strip those out and they don't look so good.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

RBC incoming.

BE11:24am

Admiral reported Group Profit before tax for 1H17 of £194.5m, 2% ahead of consensus (£191.2m) but 5% below our estimate of £203.8m. The miss to our estimate was due to lower UK Car result of £224.2m (3% below RBCe of £230.6m) and a higher loss in the International segment of - £10.1m (RBCe: loss of £8.1m). The results for the other segments (UK Household & Vans and Price Comparison) were largely in line with our estimates. Admiral announced an interim dividend of 56p (formed of normal divided of 37.9p and special dividend of 18.1p), in line with our 56.1p estimate and slightly ahead of consensus (55.5p).

BE11:25am

Unlike DLG, Admiral did not release any additional reserves from its initial Ogden claims. The company flagged that the impact of the lower Ogden rate will be recognised in the form of lower profit commissions and reserve releases in the next two to four years.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Admiral grew its total UK motor premiums 7% year on year to £966.7m versus our £998.7m estimate. We would note that Admiral grew its premiums slower than its listed UK motor peers year on year (DLG 9.9%, Hastings 27.8%, esure 27.4%). Admiral had flagged at its FY16 results presentation that volumes in this business started off the year slowly and this is visible in the results. Earnings in the business grew 1% year on year despite a strong pricing in UK motor insurance.

BE11:25am

The International business made a loss of £10.1m versus our £8.1m estimate. The combined ratio in this business was 123% at 1H17, an improvement on the 131% combined ratio a year ago but still a long way off profitability. The loss ratio improved 2 points year on year to 78% but is still far higher than the UK motor loss ratio of 66.5%. In order for the business to achieve underwriting profitability, Admiral will either need to reduce expenses or grow even faster than the current rate.

BE11:26am

Admiral flagged that it expects to submit its Solvency II internal model application in Q4 2018, a delay from the 2017 submission that it discussed at the FY16 results in March 2017 due to a change in scope to include market risk. The move to an internal model should benefit Admiral as it should lead to reduced capital requirements in our view.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

Just thinking .... About a year or so ago, following the departure of founder Henry Engelhardt, we had all sorts of rumours that Admiral might consider whether its future should be standalone.

BE11:28am

And more recently we've had all sorts of rumours that eSure's Peter Wood was considering whether its future should be standalone.

BE11:28am

Neither story seemed to come to anything, to be clear. But interesting that the rumours should pop up a wee bit before what could be the cyclical downturn for the sector.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Anyway, here's Goldman.

BE11:30am

Operationally, Admiral’s results were largely unsurprising. UK car insurance growth remains steady, with competitiveness improving in 2Q17 as peers re-price post Ogden. Admiral’s ultimate loss ratio projections have not moved much, but the company notes that this reflects its prudent approach; given Admiral’s track-record of reserving prudence historically, this does not appear to be an area of concern in our view. Elsewhere, the UK home operation continues to grow well, and the US price comparison website has reported reduced losses, with the company also lowering FY17 loss guidance/expectations, which we see as a positive development.
Overall, we see this as a solid set of results. We would expect the shares to underperform today, given the reduced clarity on the group’s capital position/dividend potential, and since the stock has performed well in recent weeks. However, we see the UK motor performance as relatively encouraging, and marked (as ever) by a prudent approach. Progress from UK home and Compare.com in the U.S. are also relatively positive.

undefined
11:30 am
BE11:30am

Important correction from Arash.

BE11:30am

Angel - Superdry shut down and now is a sofa.com

BE11:30am

Thumbs up

11:31 am
BE11:31am

We apologise both to Superdry and sofa.com.

undefined
BE11:32am

So .............. Why the talk on the right about AA? Have I missed news?

11:32 am
AA PLC (AA.:LSE): Last: 188.10, down 1.9 (-1.00%), High: 190.70, Low: 188.00, Volume: 724.93k
BE11:32am

I mean, there's the obvious news, the Bob Mackenzie news.

BE11:33am

But that was a few weeks ago and, as it involves a lot of lawyers, I don't really think we should be typing live about it.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Otherwise, there's Jefferies saying it needs a rights issue.

BE11:34am

Which it always did, because the capital structure it floated on was a bad joke ...... but the idea here is that a change of management might make fixing the balance sheet more possible.

BE11:04am

Yep, that'd be me. Sorry.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

So, farewell div.

BE11:35am

There is a gating covenant in the bonds that is 3% from breach on our estimates. If (senior) net debt to EBITDA rises to 5.5x (JEFe: 5.3x) then the dividend can no longer be paid. Given new management, we now forecast no further dividend payments. All other things being equal we expect the group would be just below 3.0x net debt to EBITDA by 2025 versus just below 5.0x previously. The debt service covenants themselves look more comfortable requiring c50% downgrades depending on other moving parts in cash.

BE11:35am

And get the cap out.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

A rights issue to further assist de-leverage would result in a material one-off write off of interest payments. We estimate a £1.3bn rights issue would repay the £500m A3 notes and £700m A5 notes for a £102m one-off. In that scenario the balance sheet would de-lever to 3.5x and fall below 2.0x by FY23. In this note we present a scenario analysis of shares issued at 20-45% below the current share price which puts the PE multiple at 13.5x TERP - still too rich given the near term concerns and longer structural headwinds.

BE11:36am

So, continue to avoid.

BE11:36am

With the equity component now worth only just over 25% of the EV, the shares are likely to be volatile. While we do not formally assume a rights issue in our estimates, we value the shares assuming that £1.3bn is raised to repair the balance sheet at a 20% discount to the current share price. We then value the shares on 12x PE given the growth characteristics of the sector and business. This drives a reduced 150p price target (from 180p) and unchanged Underperform recommendation. Upside risk from successful initiatives driving faster EPS growth and bond refinancing at low rates.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

On AA, I also recommend the Credit Suisse note from August 8.

BE11:39am

Does a good teardown of AA being a premium priced product in a market that's both seriously difficult to organise and seriously exposed to the lack of wage inflation we noted earlier.

BE11:39am

The AA has faced significant challenges in the past year in meeting the surges in breakdown call-outs. This has been attributed to the nature of the contracts of the patrol staff with respect to flexibility and overtime requirements. As a consequence when the peaks in call-outs cannot be met internally this leads to increased garaging which places incremental pressure on the margin.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Whilst the AA has previously advised that increased call-outs helps to generate higher levels of retention (with c.90% retention rates of customers using the service) we challenge this assertion when the increased call-out levels are serviced by higher levels of garaging services which is of mixed quality.

BE11:39am

The margin will feel further pressure, in our view, from discounting. With the FCA transparency requirement (and to a lesser extent the rise in IPT) raising awareness of the renewal price we believe this will increase volume through the “Stay AA” system with discounts provided to encourage customers to remain.

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Carlsberg, referred to on the right ........ not on my watchlist, sorry.

BE11:41am

Conference call seemed to go okay.

BE11:41am

At least according to Liberum.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Carlsberg are focused on executing their efficiency program, which the market seems to underappreciate because management did not put a margin or ROIC target on the program. Carlsberg are delivering strong results in the face of material headwinds outside of their control (i.e., Russia PET, India highway ban/GST). We believe that aggressive pricing in Russia is unsustainable and should improve given the recent ABI/Efes tie up. Strong free cash flow generation coupled with an under-levered balance sheet provides Carlsberg the cushion to lift their stake in Habeco and to increase shareholder returns given that they are close the bottom of their 1.5-2x net debt/EBITDA target. Carlsberg trades on attractive multiples and today's results confirm that the company is able to execute its self-help program.

BE11:42am

Results mixed rather than good.

BE11:42am

Despite missing on both organic volumes and organic sales, Carlsberg reported organic EBIT growth of 15%, well ahead of the consensus for +7%. Each of the regions beat on EBIT. Lower interest costs helped the company deliver a 12% EPS beat. Surprisingly, management upheld FY guidance for a mid-single digit organic increase in EBIT despite the 15% delivered in H1, blaming tough comps and further investments. The call is at 8am UK time.

Eastern Europe was the biggest driver of the sales disappointment in H117 with sales missing consensus by 8%. EBIT margins, however, exceeded consensus by 263bps, rising 320bps y-o-y. The Russian beer market fell 5% over the 6 month period, implying a modest deterioration in Q2. For the FY, management continues to expect a market decline of 5% in volume terms due to the restrictions on PET packaging.
Asia margins expanded 200bps y-o-y despite flat volumes in H1 as premiumisation efforts paid off. Volume grew 3% organically in China, a clear improvement on recent trends, driven by Tuborg, Carlsberg and 1664 Blanc. India (volumes up double digits) recovered in Q2 after falling 15% (ex-Bihar) in Q1. However, management maintains a cautious outlook for the country, given the GST implementation and the roadside alcohol ban. Vietnam was unexpectedly weak and the local management has been replaced.
Western Europe was the only region to meet top-line expectations. Volumes here were +1% on an organic basis. All markets except the UK saw good growth rates. The company is focusing on craft and premium brands in the troubled UK market, but this will take time to show up in the numbers. Margins rose 160bps y-o-y.
Investment view. Carlsberg is making progress on its portfolio rationalisation and cost savings efforts. New management is delivering on the Sail22 objectives. However, the geographic exposure to currently challenged Beer markets (Russia, India, China) makes us cautious about the near term direction of forecasts. Today’s results confirm the challenges that Carlsberg faces are ongoing.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

That was Investec.

BE11:42am

And consumer staples have, you don't need me to tell you, been a hell of a market this year already.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

ROTR notes this morning's blast from The Trumpet

BE11:43am

https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/897763049226084352

BE11:45am

Whatever could Mr Trump have against Amazon, whose founder just happens to own the Washington Post?

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Truly, it's a mystery.

BE11:46am

Anyway, while on US retail .....

BE11:47am

The overnight warning from Dick's Sporting Goods was noted on the right.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Q2 stank. Absolutely stank, even against low expectations. Dicks blames competition in the hunting & athletic apparel categories

BE11:49am

Otherwise, same old story really. Online cannibalises stores where it makes a positive impact, but mostly it's just losing sales to Amazon.

BE11:49am

Direct readthrough would be for Sports Direct, of course.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

Which has just over 2% of Dicks, by memory.

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 417.20, up 4.1 (+0.99%), High: 420.90, Low: 410.30, Volume: 316.05k
BE11:50am

And whose project to become the Selfridges of trainer stores is, let's be polite here, a work in progress.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Most things here (from Citi) can apply equally to SPD and to a lesser extent JD.

BE11:53am

We are worried that we heard echoes of dept stores in today's commentary: 1) discounting in order to compete and 2) increasing private label. We see near-term challenges to both comps and margins from the new pricing environment. Long term we still think that DKS is a survivor (Brushing up on BBY's Playbook) but with no catalyst over the next 12 months and a price war as well as strategic investments expected to carry into 2018, we downgrade DKS to Neutral.

DKS plans to take aggressive action to defend share and highlight value in an environment where some categories have become either over distributed (e.g. athletic apparel) or irrationally priced (e.g. hunt due to inventory overhang). When we have seen other retailers make price investments (e.g. BBY) they have been accompanied by SG&A offsets to help soften the blow. DKS is benefitting from bringing e-comm in-house and has trimmed in some areas (store support center) but overall strategic investments remain elevated (e.g. Team Sports HQ) and are likely to further depress earnings for now. The level of pullback in the stock and less than 4x EV/EBITDA makes it an intriguing valuation given there are very few retailers in our space (including FINL, BBBY, ODP) that are trading at that level. However, given the negative sentiment surrounding retail and the lack of catalysts, valuation is likely to be range bound.

BE11:53am

And JPM.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

What concerns us most is the inventory in the athletic apparel channel is "not that bad,” according to management, and thus rational pricing won't per se return until the brands find inventory and channel discipline and arguably recognize the US market is mature (vs. increasing inventory to the department stores over the past five years). DKS arguably falls into the long-term survivor bucket of retail, but needs the vendors to behave better, in our view (a la Samsung and BBY).

BE11:53am

But that's enough Dick's.

undefined
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Several requests for Epwin ....

BE11:54am

Down 20% at pixel.

Epwin Group PLC (EPWN:LSE): Last: 78.47, down 16.53 (-17.40%), High: 85.00, Low: 75.00, Volume: 1.61m
11:55 am
BE11:55am

Warning full-year will be "marginally below expectations"

BE11:55am

In spite of the first half matching.

BE11:56am

Actually, let me quote Shore. Getting bored of typing.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

Part one relates to weak overall demand conditions in the PVCu replacement windows market which, according to management, will cause FY2017 numbers to be “marginally below market expectations”. As we have heard from the builders merchants, residential RMI (repair/maintenance/improvement) spend is being impacted by a general slowdown in UK consumer demand and sluggish housing transactions.
Part two is company specific. Epwin use specialist distributors to get their product to end market. Today management highlighted the risk of losing the business of two distribution clients, each accounting for 5% of group sales. Customer one is in financial difficulty and customer two has been acquired by a competitor of the group. No further details were provided with management stating that “the implications…are unclear at this stage”

BE11:57am

And Panmure for new forecasts.

BE11:57am

We are maintaining our FY17 revenue forecasts of £300m. That said, given the macro environment (i.e. weak RMI) we are reducing our FY18 growth forecasts from 2.6% to 0.6%.
Given the pricing environment (for finished and pre-fabricated product) and the input cost inflation, we are reducing our FY17 earnings forecasts. We are now assuming that EBIT margins contract from 8.7% in FY16 to 7.9% in FY17 (previous estimate 8.6%). As a consequence, we anticipate FY17 EBIT of £23.8m.
We believe free cash flow remains healthy and expect operational cash generation (post maintenance capex) of £17.2m. This puts the shares on a FCF yield of 13.6% (FY17). Given the market position and low level of leverage (0.6x Dec-17 est.) investors have already priced in all of the uncertainties (and more).

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Also, Liberum saying there's no readthrough to Safestyle, on which they're shop.

BE11:59am

This should not read across to Safestyle which has already given a trading update on the same period. Epwin has also warned that two big customers (each around 5% of sales) could see disrupted order patterns as one is in financial distress and the other (likely SIG Plastics) has recently been sold, and this is likely to cause weakness in its shares rather than the outlook statement. Epwin is exposed to UK replacement windows but also wider building materials for RMI (repair, maintenance and improvement) as well as new build social. Safestyle is continuing to gain share and is expected to maintain profits in a weak market. Its shares trade at 11.0x 2018E PER and it is expected to have cash on its balance sheet worth around 9% of its market cap.

Safestyle UK PLC (SFE:LSE): Last: 225.75, down 1.75 (-0.77%), High: 228.75, Low: 225.00, Volume: 20.45k
11:59 am
BE11:59am

And that's all I have there.

undefined
BE12:00pm

Ooh.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Tuesday 29th August 2017 marks the start of the two-year countdown for consumers to make a complaint about payment protection insurance (PPI). The 29th also sees the start of the FCA campaign which is designed to raise awareness of the deadline and encourage consumers to make a decision about whether to make a PPI complaint or not.

The FCA will be unveiling the campaign creative at a press conference at 8am on 29th August 2017. At the press conference, we will reveal our television, social media and out of home adverts, which are designed to cut through the noise around PPI. Journalists will have an opportunity to experience the full range of advertising and ask questions about the campaign and our supervisory approach.

BE12:00pm

Hang on, is that on embargo?

BE12:01pm

Oh. No, no it isn't. It's a warning that it'll be on embargo later.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Anyway, good to see the FCA spending cash on raising awareness about PPI.

BE12:02pm

Targeting the message to reach those folk who live under five or more rocks.

BE12:02pm

Anyway, that's midday.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

(@Fatdaz: that was Geoff Ruddell, IIRC, who we quote at every opportunity. He's very good.)

BE12:03pm

Cheers for joining.

BE12:04pm

Back tomorrow. Hopefully as a dialogue.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Until then, afternoon all.

BE11:35am

New management, unencumbered by association with the IPO both in terms of forecasts and capital structure, could bring fresh perspectives. Clearly that brings a risk that estimates are reset and that capital allocation and capital structure are reviewed.
